user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_init:
```c
void
MHD_init (void)
{
#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  WSADATA wsd;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */

  MHD_set_panic_func (NULL, NULL);

#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (0 != WSAStartup (MAKEWORD (2, 2), &wsd))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialize winsock.\n"));
  if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
#ifdef MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT
#if GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER < 0x010600
#if GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_pthread))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#elif defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_w32))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#endif /* defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_) */
#endif /* GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00 */
  gcry_check_version (NULL);
#else
  if (NULL == gcry_check_version ("1.6.0"))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("libgcrypt is too old. MHD was compiled for " \
                  "libgcrypt 1.6.0 or newer.\n"));
#endif
#endif /* MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT */
  gnutls_global_init ();
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_init ();
  MHD_send_init_static_vars_ ();
  MHD_init_mem_pools_ ();
  /* Check whether sizes were correctly detected by configure */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  if (1)
  {
    struct timeval tv;
    mhd_assert (sizeof(tv.tv_sec) == SIZEOF_STRUCT_TIMEVAL_TV_SEC);
  }
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  mhd_assert (sizeof(uint64_t) == SIZEOF_UINT64_T);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the code for compiler/language extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (examples: GCC/Clang __attribute__, __extension__, __builtin_*, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({...}), nested functions, MSVC __declspec, pragma extension usage, inline asm, nonstandard keywords, or other compiler-specific language features). None of those constructs appear in the provided function.

Notes on items that might look suspicious but are NOT language extensions and thus do not need investigation under MISRA C: 
- #if, #ifdef, #else, #endif and the use of macros such as MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS, HTTPS_SUPPORT, etc. are standard preprocessor directives (not extensions).
- Calls to platform/library APIs (WSAStartup, gcry_control, gcry_check_version, gnutls_global_init, MHD_PANIC, MHD_set_panic_func, etc.) are library/platform usages, not compiler-language extensions.
- MAKEWORD, LOBYTE, HIBYTE are platform (Windows) macros — platform-specific but not compiler language extensions per se; they are defined in Windows headers.
- The backslash used to split the string literal across source lines is the standard C line-continuation mechanism / adjacent-string literal behavior, not a compiler extension.
- Use of standard types like uint64_t and struct timeval are standard C / POSIX types (or from standard headers) and not compiler extensions.
- Conditional compilation based on version-number macros (GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER, GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER) is normal portable/version-check code.

Because no explicit compiler language extensions were detected in the code fragment, there are no suspicious fragments to flag for Rule 1.2.
